awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Headwater stream networks in a warming world: predicting heterotrophic ecosystem function using theory, multi-scale temperature manipulations and modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth's river systems receive, transport, store, and break down a substantial proportion of the dead plant material produced in terrestrial ecosystems. Many of the steps in the breakdown of this organic matter are greatly affected by water temperature, which is increasing along with air temperature globally. While the effects of temperature on some of these steps are understood relatively well at small scales, it remains an open question how they interact as a complex, integrated ecosystem-level process to drive the effects of rising temperatures at the large spatial and temporal scales over which Earth's river systems operate. Consequently, research is needed that tests the effects of temperature on organic matter breakdown in whole ecosystems, with the explicit goal of scaling up these results to understand how entire river reaches and networks process organic matter. This project will use data from temperature manipulations at multiple spatial and temporal scales to: 1) inform ecological theory that uses basic principles to understand how the effects of temperature scale from individual organisms to entire ecosystems; and 2) build a model that simulates the effects of temperature on organic matter processing in an entire forest stream network. This research is important because rising temperatures may alter the global biogeochemical role of streams and rivers in currently unpredictable ways, making the results useful in the future management of river health. An education program will be an integral part of this project and will include the development of a citizen science project, as well as training of undergraduates, graduate students and research technicians.
	Fieldwork for this project will take place at the Coweeta Hydrologic Laboratory, North Carolina, U.S.A., a site with a decades-long history of research on organic matter processing in stream ecosystems. The first objective is to understand how warming affects the organisms (fungi and invertebrates) that are critically important in organic matter breakdown in streams. This component of the project will combine detailed laboratory-based studies of fungi, experiments in heated streamside channels and the warming of an entire reach of a small forest stream to understand how higher temperatures change community structure of fungal and animal decomposers. The second objective is to use the various temperature manipulations to understand how temperature changes pathways and rates of organic matter processing in streams and rivers. The fates of organic matter will be studied using laboratory investigations, streamside channels, and field experiments combined with organic matter budgets and food web descriptions in the experimentally warmed stream and a matching reference stream. The results of these first two objectives will be combined with extensive existing datasets available at the Coweeta site to inform the final objective: construction of an ecological model that predicts the effects of warming on organic matter processing in an entire stream network. This model will also allow incorporation of other important factors that could potentially change in the future, such as precipitation and the relative quality of organic matter that enters stream ecosystems. Together, this research will provide much needed information about how warming influences the important biogeochemical role of streams and rivers.

por.por_cntn:
Stream and river networks are known for their regional to global importance in carbon cycling, particularly in their transport and processing of organic carbon and carbon gases from the terrestrial environment. In headwater forested stream networks, the physical and biological breakdown of leaf litter is often the largest carbon flux pathway, and leaf litter is an important food resource for stream food webs.  In this project, we used empirical relationships between leaf litter breakdown and stream temperatures, along with streamflow and stream temperature datasets, to develop a stream network model that estimates daily leaf litter breakdown across an entire stream network. By running model scenarios that considered changes in stream temperature regimes due to latitude, atmospheric warming, and groundwater heat contributions we were able to evaluate how stream network leaf litter breakdown may change in a warming world.

We found that (1) how the timing of leaf litter fall and stream temperature peaks interacted determined the seasonal patterns of stream network leaf litter breakdown; the effects of stream temperature on leaf litter breakdown may be muted or enhanced based on the timing of leaf litter inputs; (2) leaf litter traits, and specifically those that influence whether breakdown rates are fast or slow, influenced overall breakdown patterns at the network-scale; (3) groundwater plays an important role in stream carbon cycling through its thermal contribution; groundwater-fed streams have higher breakdown during winter months when groundwater inputs moderate cold weather conditions; (4) climate warming may exacerbate the low amount of leaf litter remaining for stream food webs in summer months, particularly when stream networks are not fed by deep groundwater.

Because groundwater delivers carbon but can also alter stream temperatures, in this project we also quantified patterns of groundwater contributions within our study stream network and across the continental U.S. Groundwater discharge can buffer streams from increasing air temperatures; however, the thermal buffering capacity of groundwater discharge to stream ecosystems depend on the flow path depth of discharging groundwater.  We use paired, multi-year air and surface water temperature signals to categorize the relative contributions of shallow and deep groundwater to streamflow for 1786 stream and river sites across the continental United States. Approximately 40% of sites had a strong groundwater contribution, of which approximately 50% had shallow groundwater signatures. Sites with shallow groundwater signatures have a higher proportion of increasing long-term temperature trends compared to sites with deep groundwater signatures, which were more stable. Streams with thermal regimes closely coupled to air temperature were associated with low watershed slope and high watershed impervious coverage, indicating groundwater disconnection in human-modified landscapes. Our results emphasize that the vulnerability of streams to warming and precipitation changes associated with climate change will depend not only on groundwater connectivity, but also whether that groundwater originates from predominantly shallow or deeper sources. These results are crucial for scaling temperature-dependent carbon dynamics from stream reaches to whole networks. 

Our key outcomes are two-fold: (1) A continental-scale estimate groundwater contribution to streamflow with a web-based tool that makes the analysis publicly available for any user (https://cuahsi.shinyapps.io/pasta/).  (2) A stream network modeling framework implemented for a 3rd order forested watershed capable of quantifying the influence of changing temperature regimes (we considered atmospheric warming, latitude, and groundwater effects) on stream carbon cycling, with a specific focus on carbon fluxes from leaf litter breakdown.
